Data - Storage - State - Structure - key: Storage behaves like a key-value mapping. Values in storage are in the same order as the contract.
Data - Storage - State - Structure - slo: Each value is stored in a slot.
Each slot is 256 bits, which fits exactly a uint256 variable.
For smaller data types, slots will still have some empty bits leftover. In this case, Solidity will try to pack values together, until slots are full.
Data - Storage - State - Structures - Wo: Stores all accounts (EOAs and contracts) and their current state (balance, nonce, storage, codeHash).
Uses a modified Merkle Patricia Trie (MPT) for efficient cryptographic proofs. Each node is referenced by its Keccak-256 hash. Root hash stored in the block header (stateRoot).
A global trie where each key is a 20-byte Ethereum address (common.Address)

each value is an account state object containing: nonce, balance (in Wei, 1 ETH = 10¹⁸ Wei), storageRoot (hash of the contract's storage trie, empty for EOAs), codeHash (hash of contract bytecode, keccak256('') for EOAs).
Root Hash: The root of this trie is stored in the block header as stateRoot.
The stateObject struct in Geth holds an account's balance and other fields: core/state/state_object.go
Data - Storage - State - Structures - Ac: Each contract has its own storage trie to persist key-value pairs (e.g., balances[address]).
A sub-trie of the world state trie, referenced by storageRoot in the account.
Data - Storage - State - Database: Backing Storage: The trie nodes are stored in a key-value database (e.g., LevelDB in Geth).
Data - Storage - State - Database - Dire: In Geth, the state is stored in the chaindata directory (e.g., geth/chaindata).
Data - Storage - State - Database - Node: Trie nodes are stored under prefixes like s (state), c (code), etc. Example key: s + nodeHash → RLP-encoded node.
Data - Storage - State - StateAPI: Geth’s state API allows inspecting the trie:
Data - TransientStorage - EIP-1153: Transient storage is a relatively new addition to the protocol, introduced by EIP-1153, and is only available on networks that support it.
Data - TransientStorage - Features - tem: Your budget friendly option to storage, except that it’s temporary. It only last per transaction.
Data - TransientStorage - Usage - reentr: Transient reentrancy guards are a common use of transient storage.
Data - Memory - call: Memory is a modifiable, cheap option for dynamic data types . Dynamic data types are data types that do not have a specific size (strings, arrays, structs and mappings). Memory only “exists” per message call. Each message call gets its own memory, which is wiped clean at the end of each call.
Data - Stack: The stack is the EVM’s fast, temporary workspace for computation. It stores short-lived values such as operands, intermediate results, and all static local variables during execution. Stack operations are extremely cheap compared to memory or storage, which makes it ideal for fast calculations.
Data - CallData: Calldata is a read-only input buffer. It is used by the EVM to hold the inputs from message calls or transactions. When a message call is made, the input parameters are ABI-encoded into calldata, where they exist temporarily until the end of the message call. Values in calldata are only decoded when they are accessed. Calldata is not writable and cannot be resized.
Data - ReturnData: Returndata is a read-only output buffer. It is used by the EVM to hold the results from message calls or transactions. When a function returns a value, that value is ABI-encoded into returndata, where it exists temporarily until the caller reads it. The caller may then ABI-decode this returndata into its own memory.
Data - Code: Code is the region where the EVM stores the smart contract bytecode.
Communications - P2P: Networking (P2P) Layer. Enables communication between nodes.
Communications - JSON-RPC: Allows external interaction with the blockchain.
